issues.text: Whether the widow of the deceased appellant has the right to prosecute the appeal after his death, or does the appeal abate under section 431 CrPC?

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the State of Himachal Pradesh, who are respondents to the appeal, has raised a preliminary objection to the right of the appellants widow to prosecute the appeal. He contends that the substantive sentence of imprisonment imposed on the appellant Harnam Singh came to an end with his death and therefore the appeal in regard to that sentence stands abated. As regards the sentence of fine, it is contended that since the deceased appellant was not sentenced to pay a fine only but was punished with a composite sentence of imprisonment and fine, the appeal would abate as regards the sentence of fine also. According to the learned counsel this Court may, at the highest, set aside the sentence of fine if it finds that the appellant need not have been asked to pay a fine. But the order of conviction and the substantive sentence must remain and the legality or propriety of that order cannot any longer be questioned in view of the death of the appellant.

issues.text: Whether section 431 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898 has application to appeals filed by special leave under Article 136 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: The appeal before us was filed by special leave granted under Article 136 of the Constitution and is neither under section 411A 2 nor under section 417 nor under any other provision of Chapter XXXI of the Code. Plainly therefore, section 431 has no application, and the question whether the appeal abated on the death of the appellant is not governed strictly by the terms of that section. But, in the interests of uniformity, there is no valid reason for applying to appeals under Article 136 a set of rules different from those which govern appeals under the Code in the matter of abatement.

issues.text: Whether an appeal from a composite order of sentence combining substantive imprisonment with fine is, for the purposes of section 431 CrPC, an appeal from a sentence of fine?

anchor.surface_text: The narrow question which then requires to be considered is whether an appeal from a composite order of sentence combining the substantive imprisonment with fine is for the purposes of section 431 an appeal from a sentence of fine. It is true that an appeal from a composite order of sentence is ordinarily directed against both the substantive imprisonment and the fine. But, such an appeal does not for that reason cease to be an appeal from a sentence of fine.

issues.text: Whether on the evidence it was established that the accused had accepted the bribe from the complainant?
Whether the violation of section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act has caused prejudice to the accused and has resulted in miscarriage of justice?

holdings.text: Section 431 of the Code of Criminal Procedure has no application to appeals filed by special leave under Article 136 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal before us was filed by special leave granted under Article 136 of the Constitution and is neither under section 411A 2 nor under section 417 nor under any other provision of Chapter XXXI of the Code. Plainly therefore, section 431 has no applic

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeals under Article 136 are not under Chapter XXXI provisions to which s.431 expressly applies.

holdings.text: In interests of uniformity, appeals under Article 136 are governed by same abatement rules as appeals under the Code.

anchor.surface_text: But, in the interests of uniformity, there is no valid reason for applying to appeals under Article 136 a set of rules different from those which govern appeals under the Code in the matter of abatement. It is therefore necessary to find the true mea

holdings.reasoning_summary: Uniformity in procedure across appeal types avoids conflicting rules.

holdings.text: An appeal from a composite sentence of imprisonment and fine is an appeal from a sentence of fine for purposes of section 431 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The narrow question which then requires to be considered is whether an appeal from a composite order of sentence combining the substantive imprisonment with fine is for the purposes of section 431 an appeal from a sentence of fine. It is true that

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.431 parenthetical clause lacks 'only'; fine liability on estate persists regardless of concurrent imprisonment; no interpretive insertion needed.

holdings.text: Widow substituted as legal representative is entitled to prosecute the appeal as it is from a sentence of fine affecting the estate.

anchor.surface_text: The deceased appellant widow who has been brought on the record as his legal representative is accordingly entitled to prosecute the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fine creates direct liability on estate devolving to legal representatives.

holdings.text: In appeal from sentence of fine, court must examine conviction validity; if conviction unsustainable, set aside conviction and all sentences.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the State Government thought it anomalous... The appellate court, while dealing with the validity of the sentence of fine, has to determine the primary question whether the conviction itself is sustainable. If it holds that the convicti

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conviction foundational to sentence; invalid conviction voids derivative sentences.

holdings.text: Gondada Gajapathy Rao v. State of AP is distinguishable as no fine involved and interest of representatives remote.

anchor.surface_text: In Gondada Gajapathy Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh, the appellant was convicted by the High Court under section 302, Penal Code and was sentenced to imprisonment for life. ... This decision is, distinguishable as the appeal was not from a sente

holdings.reasoning_summary: No fine sentence; arrears claim contingent, not direct estate liability.

holdings.text: Vidya Devi v. State (Allahabad HC) and V. Govindrajalu v. State of Mysore (Mysore HC) wrongly decided on abatement of composite sentence appeals.

anchor.surface_text: In the view we have taken the decisions of the Allahabad High Court in Vidya Devi vs. State and of the Mysore High Court in V. Govindrajalu Ors. VS. State of Mysore must be held to be wrong in so far as the point of abatement is concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partial abatement (bisection) not supported by s.431 language; leads to anomaly.

holdings.text: Prosecution evidence wholly unsatisfactory; accused did not accept bribe.

anchor.surface_text: Turning to the merits of the case we find it impossible to uphold the judgment of the High Court. The main witnesses examined by the prosecution... the evidence on which the conviction is based is wholly unworthy of acceptance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partisan witnesses, hostile panchas no corroboration, procedural irregularities (no anthracene, poor recovery, discrepancies in recovery location), investigating officer misconduct.

holdings.text: Evidence of hostile panch witnesses does not corroborate partisan prosecution witnesses on bribe acceptance.

anchor.surface_text: At the outset of its judgment... The High Court, however, held that in spite of the fact that these two witnesses had turned hostile... We find it extremely difficult to appreciate how the evidence of these hostile witnesses could corroborate

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hostile witnesses reject prosecution version; cannot support partisan evidence.

holdings.text: Violation of s.5A Prevention of Corruption Act by Sub-Inspector investigating without proper disclosure caused prejudice and miscarriage of justice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Misled magistrate on availability of superior officer; no reasons in order; personal interest of investigator.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; conviction, substantive sentence, and fine set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In, the result we allow the appeal and set aside the order of conviction, the substantive sentence as also the sentence of fine.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of evidentiary and procedural failures.

precedents.citation: Gondada Gajapathy Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh 1 1964 7 S.C.R. 251

anchor.surface_text: In Gondada Gajapathy Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh  , the appellant was convicted by the High Court under section 302, Penal Code and was sentenced to imprisonment for life. He filed an appeal in this Court by special leave but died during the pendency of the appeal. His sons and daughter applied for substitution as his legal representatives contending that the conviction of their father had resulted in his removal from Government service and if the conviction were set aside the estate will be able to claim the arrears of salary from the date of conviction till the date  if his death. This Court declined to permit the legal representatives to continue the appeal on the ground that the claim on the strength of which they sought permission to continue the appeal was too remote. This decision is, distinguishable  1  1964 7 S.C.R. 251.

precedents.case_name: Gondada Gajapathy Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Legal representatives of deceased appellant cannot continue criminal appeal under Article 136 if their interest is contingent and remote such as arrears of salary after removal from service
precedents.cited_holding: Court declined to permit legal representatives to continue the appeal as the claim was too remote

precedents.citation: Vidya Devi vs. State 1 A.I.R. 1957 All. 20

anchor.surface_text: In the, view we have taken the decisions of the Allahabad High Court in Vidya Devi vs. State 1  and of the Mysore High Court in V. Govindrajalu Ors. VS. State of Mysore 2  must be held to be wrong in so far as the point of abatement is concerned.

precedents.cited_proposition: Appeal from composite sentence of imprisonment and fine abates as regards imprisonment but legal representatives can continue as regards fine

precedents.citation: V. Govindrajalu Ors. VS. State of Mysore 2 A.I.R. 1962 Mysore 275

anchor.surface_text: In the, view we have taken the decisions of the Allahabad High Court in Vidya Devi vs. State 1  and of the Mysore High Court in V. Govindrajalu Ors. VS. State of Mysore 2  must be held to be wrong in so far as the point of abatement is concerned. The Allahabad High Court took the view that an appeal from a composite order of sentence would abate as regards the sentence of imprisonment but may be continued by the legal representatives as regards the sentence of fine. This bisection of the appeal, as pointed out by us, is not justified by the language of section 431 and would lead to unjust and anomalous results. The Mysore decision assumed without any discussion that an appeal from a composite order of sentence abates partially. ... A.I.R. 1957 All. 20. A.I.R. 1962 Mysore 275.

precedents.case_name: V. Govindrajalu Ors. VS. State of Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: Appeal from composite sentence of imprisonment and fine abates partially as regards imprisonment
